questions.text:
Which of the following are the most common causes of antepartum haemorrhage?


	Placenta previa
	Placental abruption
	Uterine rupture
	Vasa Previa
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Placenta previa

Explanations

Antepartum Hemorrhage (APH) is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after the 28th week of pregnancy but before the birth of the baby.

 

Causes of antepartum haemorrhage:

 

Cause

Definition

Placenta previa

(Option A)
  • The placenta is implanted partially or completely over the lower uterine segment, causing bleeding as the cervix dilates.
  • Most common (~33%)

Placental abruption

(Option B)
  • Premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall. Causes include hypertension, trauma, and smoking.
  • Second most common

Uterine rupture

(Option C)
  • Tearing of the uterine wall. Risk factors include previous cesarean section, large baby, and prolonged labour.
  • Rare but serious

Vasa Previa

(Option D)
  • Fetal blood vessels cross the cervix, leading to bleeding when membranes rupture or during labour (rare).

Local cervical lesions
  • Includes polyps and carcinoma.

Circumvallate placenta
  • Fetal membranes fold back over the edge of the placenta.

Indeterminate bleeding
  • Vaginal bleeding in late pregnancy without a clear cause.
  • Possible causes include rupture of the marginal sinus or excessive show.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman G3P2 at 30 weeks of gestation presents with sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding. She has had no contractions. Her previous pregnancies were uncomplicated. Vital signs are stable, fetal heart rate is normal. Based on the image below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Placenta previa

Explanation

Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower segment of the uterus, either partially or completely covering the cervical os, presenting with sudden, painless, bright red bleeding. The patient’s symptoms, stable vital signs, and ultrasound findings support this diagnosis.

 

 

Placenta previa

Definition

Placenta implanted partially or completely over the lower uterine segment (within 2 cm of the cervical os), causing bleeding as the cervix dilates.

Incidence

0.5-1% of hospital deliveries, common in multiparous women

Risk Factors
  • Age > 35.
  • High birth order.
  • Multiple pregnancies.
  • Large placenta:
    • Multiple Gestations (like in twins)
    • Gestational Diabetes
    • Fetal Anomalies
    • Maternal anaemia
    • Hydrops fetalis
    • Infections (like toxoplasmosis or syphilis)

Cause of Bleed

Dilation of lower uterine segment, shearing of placenta

Symptoms

Sudden, painless bleeding, often at night, recurrent

Complications
  • Rarely associated with pre-eclampsia
  • Preterm labor
  • Severe bleeding (can lead to shock)
  • Placenta accreta spectrum
  • Malpresentation
  • C-section



 

Placental abruption (Option A): Premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, causing painful, dark red bleeding with contractions and abdominal pain. The absence of pain and the ultrasound finding makes this less likely.

 

Uterine rupture (Option B): Tearing of the uterine wall, typically associated with severe abdominal pain, history of uterine surgery, and fetal distress. The scenario lacks these symptoms and complications.

 

Vasa previa (Option D): Fetal blood vessels cross or run near the cervical os, leading to painless bleeding when membranes rupture. Usually identified via ultrasound showing vessels, not just placenta position, making this less likely in the given scenario. Sudden fetal distress is seen in this condition.

questions.text: Identify the given condition shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Marginal Placenta Previa

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the edge of the placenta reaching up to the margin of the internal os but not covering it. This is known as marginal placenta previa.

 

Types of placenta previa:

 

Types

Definitions

I

Low lying (Option D ruled out)

The placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment but does not reach the internal os.

II

Marginal

The edge of the placenta is at the margin of the internal os.

III

Incomplete/partial central (Option B ruled out)

The placenta partially covers the internal os of the cervix.

IV

Central/complete (Option A ruled out)

The placenta completely covers the internal os of the cervix.
  • Types I and II can be anterior or posterior.
  • Types I and II are minor degrees, and types III and IV are major degrees of placenta previa.
  • Type 2 posterior is known as dangerous placenta previa as it is more likely to be compressed, producing cord compression. This can lead to fetal asphyxia and death.

Revised Classification:

Types

Definitions

True Placenta previa

The placenta covers the internal os

Low lying placenta

The placenta lies within 2cm of internal is but does not cover it

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor associated with the development of placenta previa during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) High blood pressure

 

Explanation:

High blood pressure is more commonly associated with placental abruption and pre-eclampsia, not placenta previa, it can be associated with small placenta.

Risk factors for Placenta previa

  • Previous Cesarean Delivery (Increased risk due to potential scarring on the uterine wall).
  • Previous h/o placenta previa.
  • Multiple Pregnancies.
  • Advanced Maternal Age (Women over 35 are at a higher risk).
  • Smoking.
  • Uterine Surgery (Surgeries such as myomectomy and hysterotomy).
  • Multiple Gestations.
  • Infertility Treatments
  • Big placenta

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports no pain, contractions, or bleeding. An ultrasound performed at 20 weeks showed a placenta previa that remained stable on follow-up ultrasound. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Immediate hospitalisation and preparation for emergency C-section
Expectant management with periodic transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) and implementation of the McAfee Johnson regimen
Administration of magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection and immediate delivery
Routine follow-up with monthly abdominal ultrasounds without activity restrictions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Expectant management with periodic transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) and implementation of the McAfee Johnson regimen

 

Explanation:

The recommended management involves expectant management in a stable case of placenta previa with no active bleeding or other complications. This includes periodic Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) monitoring and following the McAfee and Johnson regimen.

 

McAfee and Johnson regime:

It is an expectant management strategy for patients with placenta previa to ensure maternal and fetal safety while aiming to prolong the pregnancy.

 

Indications:
  • The mother is healthy (Hb >10 g % and haematocrit > 30%).
  • Absence of active vaginal bleeding.
  • Gestational age <37 weeks.
  • Reactive CTG.

Steps in McAfee and Johnson regime:
  1. Hospitalise the patient (Bed rest).
  2. Monitoring:
    1. Maternal vitals.
    2. Fetal heart sounds.
    3. Bleeding.
  3. Arrange for blood.
  4. If the patient is Rh (-ve), anti-D should be given.
  5. Injection of corticosteroids to hasten lung maturity of the fetus.
  6. Short-term tocolytic (nifedipine) should be provided if any contractions are present.
  7. If pregnancy <32 weeks: MgSO4 (neural protection).
 

The above-mentioned steps are continued till 37 weeks, after which elective cesarean section can be done.

 

Immediate hospitalisation and preparation for emergency C-section (Option A): No need for now since no bleeding, pain or contractions.

Administration of magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection and immediate delivery (Option C): MgSO4 only in case of extreme preterms and no indication for immediate delivery for now. 

Routine follow-up with monthly abdominal ultrasounds without activity restrictions (Option D): No need of monthly scans and it is advised to avoid exertion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G2P1, at 37 weeks gestation presents with painless, bright red vaginal bleeding. At her 20-week ultrasound, the placenta was found to be located in the lower uterine segment. On physical examination, her vital signs are stable, but the bleeding is ongoing. Ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of placenta previa with placenta edge within 2 cm from internal os. What is the definitive step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Artificial rupture of membrane with vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Immediate cesarean delivery

 

Explanation:

In the management of unstable placenta previa with ongoing bleeding at or after 37 weeks of pregnancy, the priority is active/definite management with immediate cesarean delivery.

 

Active/Definite management in placenta previa:
Indications: Mode of delivery:
  • Unstable maternal vitals.
  • Active bleeding present.
  • Period of gestation:
    • > 37 weeks.
    • ≥ 34 weeks with extreme blood loss.
  • Fetal distress on CTG.
  • USG showing fetal anomaly incompatible with life.
  • Practically, all women with placenta previa undergo cesarean delivery to prevent maternal mortality.
  • Normal delivery can be attempted if the placental edge is >2-3 cm away from the internal os.
    • Internal examination can be done in the operating room, and induction can be done with ARM ± oxytocin.
    • Satisfactory progress of labour → Vaginal delivery.

 

Blood transfusion and hemodynamic stabilization (Option A): will be required but not the definitive management 

Artificial rupture of membrane with vaginal delivery (Option B): not done in placenta previa 

Administration of tocolytic therapy (Option D): no indication to do that

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset vaginal bleeding and severe abdominal pain. On examination, her abdomen is tender, and she shows signs of fetal distress. What is the most likely cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

 

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical Features:

  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain
  • Fetal distress
  • Hypovolemic shock

 

Placenta previa (Option A) typically presents in the third trimester and is not associated with severe abdominal pain or fetal distress.

 

Cervical polyp (Option C) are benign growths on the cervix that can cause intermittent bleeding. They are not typically associated with severe abdominal pain or fetal distress.

 

Placental infarction (Option D) typically presents with chronic or intermittent bleeding and is not associated with the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and fetal distress.

questions.text: Placental abruption begins with rupture of a spiral decidual artery and hemorrhage into the decidua basalis., and the bleeding is maternal. Which type of placental abruption is considered most dangerous ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Concealed

 

Explanation:

  • In concealed hemorrhage, blood accumulates behind the placenta as a retroplacental hematoma, separating and compressing it.
  • Since external bleeding is minimal or absent, diagnosis is often delayed, increasing risks to both mother and fetus.
  • The expanding clot raises pressure in the intervillous space, pushing placental thromboplastin into the mother’s circulation and increasing the risk of consumptive coagulopathy. 

Types of abruptio placenta:

Revealed
  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed
  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed
  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe abdominal pain and per-vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender, the pulse rate is 110 bpm, and BP is 90/60 mm Hg. Fetal heart sounds are absent. What grade of abruptio placentae is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3

 

Explanation:

The patient has per-vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain (uterine tenderness), haemodynamic instability (increased pulse rate and hypotension), and absent fetal heart sounds. It indicates grade 3 abruptio placentae.

 

Abruptio placentae- A form of antepartum haemorrhage where bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

 

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding abruptio placentae is incorrect?

choices.text: The higher the birth order, the lower the risk
Mother’s increased age increases the risk
Maternal hypertension is a risk factor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The higher the birth order, the lower the risk

 

Explanation:

When the birth order increases, the risk of placental abruption increases.

 

Risk factors for placental abruption:

General factors
  • High birth order pregnancies with gravid ≥ 5.
  • Advancing age of the mother (Option B)
  • Poor socioeconomic condition.
  • Low nutritional state.
  • Smoking (Vasospasm).

Hypertension in pregnancy (Option C)
  • Pre-eclampsia, gestational hypertension and essential hypertension are all associated (10–50%).
  • Mechanism: Spasm of the vessels in the uteroplacental bed (decidual spiral artery) → anoxic endothelial damage → rupture of vessels and extravasation of blood in the decidua basalis (retroplacental hematoma).

Trauma
  • Traumatic separation of the placenta usually leads to its marginal separation with the escape of blood outside.
  • The trauma may be
    • External cephalic version, especially under anaesthesia, using great force.
    • Road traffic accidents, blunt trauma or blows on the abdomen.
    • Needle puncture at amniocentesis.

Sudden uterine decompression
  • It leads to the diminished surface area of the uterus adjacent to the placental attachment and results in the shearing of the placenta.
  • Clinical situations are:
  • Following delivery of the first baby of twins.
  • Sudden escape of liquor amnii in polyhydramnios.
  • Premature rupture of the membranes (PROM).

Short cord
  • Relative or absolute, mechanical pull can bring about placental separation during labour.

Supine hypotension syndrome
  • There is passive engorgement of the uterine and placental vessels, resulting in rupture and extravasation of the blood.

Placental anomaly
  • Circumvallate placenta.

Folic acid deficiency

  

Uterine factors
  • Placenta implanted over a septum (septate uterus).
  • Submucous fibroid.

Torsion of the uterus (Option D)
  • Increased venous pressure and rupture of the veins with separation of the placenta.

Cocaine abuse
  • Increased risk of transient hypertension, vasospasm and placental abruption.

Thrombophilias
  • Inherited and acquired.

Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • It is associated with recurrent abruption.

Previous h/o abruption
  • The risk of recurrence varies from 5-17%.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about abruptio placentae findings?

choices.text: It is more commonly associated with malpresentation.
USG shows placenta in the upper segment.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is more commonly associated with malpresentation.

 

Explanation:

Malpresentations are most commonly associated with placenta previa.

 

Comparison of findings in placenta previa and abruptio placentae:

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is NOT true regarding Couvelaire's uterus?

choices.text: Blood extravasates into uterine musculature & beneath serosa.
A hysterectomy is indicated because the uterus is not salvageable

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A hysterectomy is indicated because the uterus is not salvageable.

 

Explanation:

Couvelaire’s uterus is not an indication for hysterectomy

Couvelaire’s uterus:

Feature

Description

Definition
  • Massive intravasation of blood into uterine musculature up to the serous coat due to severe concealed abruptio placentae (Options A, D).

Diagnosis
  • Laparotomy (Option B).

Naked Eye Features
  • The uterus appears dark port wine in colour, which may be patchy or diffuse.
  • Subperitoneal petechial haemorrhages and broad ligament haematomas.

Microscopic Appearance
  • Necrosis of uterine muscles in affected areas with infiltration of blood and fluid between muscle bundles.

Post-Delivery Considerations
  • Rarely affects uterine contractions post-delivery.
  • It is not an indication for hysterectomy (Option C).

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks gestation presents with severe abdominal pain, followed by per-vaginal bleeding. She reports a history of recent trauma after a car accident. The patient is not in labor. On physical examination, she is found to be unstable, and fetal heart rate monitoring shows fetal distress. Immediate resuscitation efforts are initiated. What is the definitive management for this case?

choices.text: Continue to observe and wait for normal vaginal delivery
Induction of labour by low rupture of membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate cesarean section

 

Explanation:

Given is a scenario of the revealed type of abruptio placentae. Fetal distress is an indication of Cesarean section in abruptio placentae.

 

Vaginal delivery is favoured in:
  1. Limited placental abruption.
  2. FHR tracing is reassuring.
  3. Facilities for continuous fetal monitoring are available.
  4. The prospect of vaginal delivery is soon.
  5. Placental abruption with a dead fetus.

Cesarean section is favoured in:
  1. Bleeding continues, and the placental abruption is greater than in Grade 1.
  2. Severe abruption with a live fetus.
  3. An amniotomy could not be done due to an unfavourable cervix.
  4. The prospect of immediate vaginal delivery is remote despite attempts.
  5. Amniotomy failed to control bleeding.
  6. Amniotomy failed to arrest the process of abruption, evidenced by rising fundal height or the appearance of adverse features (e.g., fetal distress, falling fibrinogen level, oliguria).

 Continue to observe and wait for normal vaginal delivery (Option A): It is incorrect because the mother is unstable and the fetus is in distress. Delaying delivery can worsen both maternal and fetal outcomes.
Observation is contraindicated in the setting of suspected abruption with hemodynamic compromise.

Induction of labour by low rupture of membrane (Option C): It is inappropriate in this setting. Labour induction takes time and is unsafe when:

  • There is maternal instability

  • Fetal distress is present

  • There is a need for urgent delivery
